column1: Aramaic: served variously as a language of administration of empires and as a language of divine worship. It became the lingua franca of the Neo-Assyrian Empire (911â€“605 BC), Neo-Babylonian Empire (605â€“539 BC), the Achaemenid Empire (539â€“323 BC), the Parthian Empire (247 BCâ€“224 AD), and the Sasanian Empire (224â€“651)
Syriac: Primarily a Christian medium of expression, Syriac had a fundamental cultural and literary influence on the development of Arabic, which largely replaced it towards the 14th century.
